Knowledge Point: A pronoun, as taním and ɡa in (\ref{ex:10-1}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{taním} \textbf{ɡa} na láad-u | \gls 3PL.ERG anything NEG find.PFV"=MSG | \glt `They didn't find anything.'

Knowledge Point: A nominalised clause, as the one headed by the Verbal Noun thainií in (\ref{ex:10-2}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{putríi} \textbf{ǰhaní} \textbf{thainií} zarurí bháanu | \gls son-GEN marriage do.VN necessity become.PRS"=MSG | \glt `It is necessary to get one's son married [lit: Making a~son's marriage becomes a~necessity].'

Knowledge Point: Or a~noun head, with or without preceding modifiers, as can be seen in (\ref{ex:10-3}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{ṣiṣ-íi} \textbf{so} \textbf{tuúš} \textbf{tukṛá} \textbf{mhaás} aṭ-í \textbf{qábur} the aṭ-í tíi wée ḍhanɡóol-u | \gls head-GEN DEF.MSG.NOM some piece flesh bring-CV grave to bring-CV 3SG.OBL in bury.PFV"=MSG | \glt `[He] brought some piece of the flesh to the grave and buried it there.'

Knowledge Point: \textbf{Adjectives or adjective phrases} are descriptive in nature, often capturing inherent properties or qualities of the entity referred to by the head noun. They may consist of a~single adjective, as ɡáaḍu in (\ref{ex:10-4}).
Content 1: \gll so ba \textbf{ɡáaḍ-u} \textbf{maidóon} | \gls 3MSG.NOM TOP big-MSG field | \glt `It was a~big field.'

Knowledge Point: An adjective phrase can also be complex. It can consist of two or more adjectives, symmetrically related to each other, such as dhríɡi and bhakúli in (\ref{ex:10-5}), both pointing to certain characteristics of the noun they modify.
Content 1: \gll se insaan-á \textbf{áa} \textbf{dhríɡ-i} \textbf{bhakúl-i} \textbf{lhaléemi} ɡhin-í | \gls DEF human-OBL IDEF long-F thick-F stick take-CV | \glt `The man took a~long, thick stick{...}'

Knowledge Point: The adjective head can also itself be modified, usually by a~scalar quantifier, such as bíiḍu modifying mhoóru and šišáwu in (\ref{ex:10-6}), assuming that the noun can have more or less of the quality implied by the modifying adjective phrase.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{bíiḍ-u} \textbf{mhoór-u} \textbf{bíiḍ-u} \textbf{šišáw-u} \textbf{šay} bh-áan-u | \gls very-MSG sweet-MSG very-MSG good-MSG thing become-PRS"=MSG | \glt `It is a very sweet and a very good thing.'

Knowledge Point: A repeated adjective, on the other hand, such as muxtalíf in (\ref{ex:10-7}), usually signifies a~distributive meaning.\footnote{Although the adjective phrase in the example is predicative, it still illustrates the point.}
Content 1: \gll tasíi xaaneé \textbf{muxtalíf} \textbf{muxtalíf} yháand-a | \gls 3SG.GEN shelf.PL different different come.PRS"=MPL | \glt `There are different kinds of shelves.'

Knowledge Point: (\ref{ex:10-8})--(\ref{ex:10-11}). They therefore
Content 1: \gll tarkaáṇ \textbf{maṇḍaw-íi} \textbf{kráam} široó th-áan-u | \gls carpenter veranda-GEN work start do-PRS"=MSG | \glt `The carpenter starts making the veranda [lit: starts the work of the veranda].'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{díiš-e} \textbf{xálaka} ǰamá bhe | \gls village-GEN people collected become.CV | \glt `The village people used to gather{...}'

Knowledge Point: \textbf{Quantifiers or quantifier phrases} are as a~modifier category rather heterogeneous and comprise a~few subclasses. One easily distinguishable subclass is cardinal numerals. Used alone, they simply specify quantity, as in (\ref{ex:10-12}). They can also, as seen in (\ref{ex:10-13}), be modified themselves by e.g., taqriibán (often pronounced qariibán) `about, approximately', a~Perso"=Arabic loan, and thereby become a~bit more relative.
Content 1: \gll so ta bač bhil-u \textbf{trúu} \textbf{ǰáan-a} ba hiimeel-í híṛ-a | \gls 3MSG.NOM CNTR saved become.PFV"=MSG three person-PL TOP glacier-OBL take.away.PFV"=MPL | \glt `He was saved, but three persons were taken by the avalanche.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{qaribán} \textbf{bhiíš} \textbf{kaal-á} maxadúši | \gls about twenty year-PL before | \glt `About twenty years ago...'

Knowledge Point: While cardinal numerals can be used only to modify count nouns, scalar quantifiers, such as tuúš `some' (\ref{ex:10-14}) and úča `a few' (\ref{ex:10-15}) are used to quantify mass nouns as well as count nouns in plural. Some of these are also freely used in adverbial constructions, for instance to modify adjectives, adverbs or entire clauses. One particularly frequent multipurpose modifier is bíiḍu `much, many, very'.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{tuúš} \textbf{čhoót} míi se yaar-íi rumeel-í maǰí ɡhaṇḍ-í wíi-a keé-na ɡal-úum | \gls some cheese 1SG.GEN DEF friend-GEN handkerchief-OBL in tie-CV water-OBL why-NEG throw-1SG | \glt `Why don't I put some cheese in my friend's handkerchief and throw it into the water?'
Content 2: \gll atshareet-á \textbf{úč-a} \textbf{xálak} de | \gls Ashret-OBL few-MPL people be.PST | \glt `There were few people in Ashret.'

Knowledge Point: Another strategy for quantification, seen in (\ref{ex:10-16}) and (\ref{ex:10-17}), is by means of a partitive noun phrase. It specifies the quantity of the head noun, often itself preceded by or modified by a~cardinal numeral. Typically, but not exclusively, the nouns used in such partitive phrases denote containers or measuring terms of various kinds. In many ways it would make sense to describe higher numerals (such as 20, 100, 1000) as heads of partitive phrases, modified by the cardinal numerals 1--19 to express the numbers 21--39, etc. (see \sectref{sec:6-4}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{panǰ} \textbf{phuṭ-í} \textbf{ṣo} \textbf{phuṭ-í} \textbf{kir} dít-u síinta | \gls five foot-PL six foot-PL snow fall.PFV"=MSG CONDH | \glt `When five or six feet snow had fallen...'
Content 2: \gll máa=the \textbf{dúu} \textbf{ɡilees-í} \textbf{c̣hiír} da | \gls 1SG.NOM=to two glass-PL milk give.IMP.SG | \glt `Give me two glasses of milk!'

Knowledge Point: \textbf{Determiners} and their use in noun phrases have been described elsewhere (see \sectref{sec:5-2} and \sectref{subsec:5-2-6}). This class includes all words or phrases that have the function of singling out a~referent in contrast to other referents. It primarily identifies the referent of the noun head among a~number of potential referents. Whereas the genitive phrase modifier defines or introduces a~referent, the determiner points out a~particular referent, `this house' in (\ref{ex:10-18}), and `the man', `another day', and `other people' in (\ref{ex:10-19}), whether already defined or not.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{eení} \textbf{ɡhooṣṭ-á} šíiṭi ma seé hín-u | \gls PROX house-OBL inside 1SG.NOM fall.asleep.CV be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `I was asleep inside this house.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{se} \textbf{míiš-a} \textbf{dúi} \textbf{dees-á} baačaá wazíir o \textbf{dúi} \textbf{xálak-a} samaṭ-í ilaán thíil-i | \gls DEF man-OBL other day-OBL king minister and other people-PL gather-CV announcement do.PFV-F | \glt `Next day the man called the king, the prime minister and other people together and made an~announcement.'

Knowledge Point: \textbf{Relative clauses} (see \sectref{sec:13-6}) serve a~very similar purpose of identifying the referent, as the `brutes' in (\ref{ex:10-20}), and the `stories' in (\ref{ex:10-21}). For many relative clauses, however, it is unclear to what extent they should be considered part of the noun phrase at all or rather be analysed as entirely paratactic constructions. The latter is especially true of the so"=called co"=relative or relative"=correlative constructions common in IA languages.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{tas} \textbf{mheer-í} \textbf{ɡal-í} \textbf{zaalim"=aan-óom} dhút-a pharé ɡúuli bi de ɡíia de | \gls 3SG.ACC kill-CV throw-CV brute-PL"=OBL mouth-OBL toward bread also put.CV go.PFV.PL PST | \glt `The brutes, who had killed him, had also put bread in his mouth and left.'
Content 2: \gll xalk-íim ṣaawaá \textbf{teér} \textbf{bhíl-a} \textbf{qiseé} thawóol-a | \gls people-PL.OBL MANIP passed become.PPTC"=MPL story.PL make.do.PFV"=MPL | \glt `He had the people tell him what had happened [lit: stories which had passed].'

Knowledge Point: The head can be a~title or a~designation and the preceding apposition is usually a~proper name. Only the head, in this case hakím `ruler' in (\ref{ex:10-22}), and ṣoó `king' in (\ref{ex:10-23}), is inflected.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{ɣeirat"=xaán} \textbf{hakim-í} ɡhooṣṭ-á panaahí dawéel-i | \gls Ghairat.Khan ruler-GEN house-OBL shelter ask.for.PFV-F | \glt `He asked for shelter in the ruler Ghairat Khan's house.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{šuǰaaulmúlk} \textbf{ṣoo-íi} waxt-íi ba lo daarulxalaafá c̣hatróol-a the ɡúum | \gls Shuja.ul.Mulk king-GEN time-GEN TOP DIST.MSG.NOM capital Chitral-OBL to go.PFV.MSG | \glt `During the reign of king Shuja"=ul"=Mulk the capital was moved to Chitral.'

Knowledge Point: A complex proper name (i.e., many names referring to the same person), as in (\ref{ex:10-24}) or in (\ref{ex:10-25}), functions in much the same way, as its last component is more prominent. Quite often this component is (or has been) a~title of some kind. For short complexes, it is probably a~matter of word formation rather than apposition. The included names constitute a~single phonological word, with the last syllable of the final component receiving the main accent (or the suffix according to shift"=accent rules applied), but the preceding parts are entirely or partly deaccented.
Content 1: \gll bhiooṛkúi\sim ba \textbf{pir=saahíb} ǰáand-u de | \gls Biori.valley TOP Pir=Lord alive-MSG be.PST | \glt `In Biori vally Pir Sahib was [still] alive.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{mulaa=mhaamad=seed-á} the maalúm heensíl-u hín-u ki | \gls Mullah=Mahmad=Said-OBL to knowledge stay.PFV"=MSG be-PRS"=MSG COMP | \glt `Mullah Mahmad Said knew that...'

Knowledge Point: A special case is when the obligatory string aleehisalaám `peace be upon him' (PBUH) is added after the name of a~prophet has been uttered, according to Islamic tradition. Then the final syllable of that standard string receives the accent, as is seen in (\ref{ex:10-26}), and any inflections are attached to the end of the entire phrase.
Content 1: \gll xu \textbf{eesé} \textbf{waqt-íi} \textbf{peeɣambár} \textbf{hazrát} \textbf{iliaás} \textbf{aleehisalaam-íi} beet-í káaṇ na th-íi de | \gls but DIST.OBL time-GEN prophet lord Elijah peace.be.upon.him-GEN word-PL HOST NEG do-3SG PST | \glt `But he was not listening to Lord Ilyas [Elijah], PBUH, the prophet of the time.'

Knowledge Point: The head as well as the preceding apposition can also be common nouns. Although the apposition functions as the modifier, and as such takes the place of an~adjective phrase, both nouns together contribute almost equally to the identification or specification of the referent, `female person' and `women' in (\ref{ex:10-27}), and `shepherd' and `boy' in (\ref{ex:10-28}). Each of them can separately and independently function as a~referring noun phrase.
Content 1: \gll tas sanɡí \textbf{čúur} \textbf{páanǰ} \textbf{ǰéeni} \textbf{kuṛíina} áa ba míiš \textbf{{...}} phray-áan-a | \gls 3SG.ACC with four five female.person woman.PL one TOP man ... send-PRS"=MPL | \glt `They send with her four or five women and one man.'

Knowledge Point: In other cases, the head is a~proper name and the preceding apposition is a~kinship term. In (\ref{ex:10-29}), both the noun head, `Mullah Mahmad Said', and the head of the apposition, `grandfather', take inflections, thus displaying a~higher degree of independence (and symmetry) than the aforementioned types.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{míi} \textbf{se} \textbf{dóod-a} \textbf{mulaa=mhaamad=seed-á} the ba eesó paalawaáṇ maalúm heensíl-u hín-u | \gls 1SG.GEN DEF grandfather-OBL Mullah=Mahmad=Said-OBL to TOP REM.MSG.NOM strong.man knowledge stay.PFV"=MSG be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `My grandfather Mullah Mahmad Said knew this strong man.'

Knowledge Point: The head can also be a~common noun and the preceding apposition a~pronoun. The role of the pronoun, `we' in (\ref{ex:10-30}) and `you' in (\ref{ex:10-31}), is not much different from that of a~determiner.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{be} \textbf{páanǰ} \textbf{ǰáan-a} ba ɡíia | \gls 1PL.NOM five person-PL TOP go.PFV.PL | \glt `The five of us left.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{tu} \textbf{ateeṇ-ú} \textbf{takṛá} \textbf{íṇc̣-a} díi ma kanáa bhe uḍhíiw"=um? | \gls 2SG.NOM such-MSG strong bear-OBL from 1SG.NOM like.what become.CV flee-1SG | \glt `How can I flee from such as strong bear as you?'

Section: Word order in the noun phrase
Knowledge Point: Although it is possible to use more than two modifiers in the same noun phrase, it is not too common in natural speech, and therefore the following description of the relative word order should be regarded as a~presentation of tendencies more than as hard and fast rules without exceptions. The clearest tendencies can be seen in the order of genitive phrases, determiners, quantifiers and adjective phrases with respect to each other. The following order seems to be more or less fixed: Genitive NP + Determiner + Quantifier + AP + Head. The determiner, se in (\ref{ex:10-32}) and aní in (\ref{ex:10-33}), precedes the quantifier.
Content 1: \gll se dúu mítr-a | \gls DEF two friend-PL | \glt `the two friends'
Content 2: \gll aní páanǰ bhraawú | \gls PROX five brother.PL | \glt `these five brothers'

Knowledge Point: Another modifier preceding the head of the genitive NP, the definite se in (\ref{ex:10-41}) and the indefinite ak in (\ref{ex:10-42}), is normally interpreted as part of the genitive NP and as such a~modifier of the genitive noun rather than the head of the main noun phrase.

Knowledge Point: However, the order between the genitive NP and other modifiers is not entirely fixed, and although the preferred order is genitive NP first, there are a~few cases, such as (\ref{ex:10-43}) and (\ref{ex:10-44}), where the preceding modifier most likely is a~direct modifier of the main noun head, `owner' and `fort' respectively, rather than being a~part of the genitive NP. Knowledge Point: Apart from a~larger variety of adjectives and adjective phrases allowed predicatively rather than attributively, even quantifiers may occur in a~predicative function. Quantifiers with the ability to inflect agree with the subject noun phrase in gender/number, as can be seen with bíiḍ- `much, many' in (\ref{ex:10-62}) and (\ref{ex:10-63}), and biǰóol- `several' in (\ref{ex:10-64}).
Content 1: \gll {\ob}\textbf{eeṛé} \textbf{šay-á}{\cb} {\ob}\textbf{bíiḍ-a}{\cb} | \gls DIST thing[M]-PL much-MPL | \glt `There are lots of those things.'
Content 2: \gll {\ob}\textbf{tasíi} \textbf{duṣmaán}{\cb} {\ob}\textbf{bíiḍ-u}{\cb} | \gls 3SG.GEN enemy[MSG] much-MSG | \glt `She has many enemies.'
Content 3: \gll atshareet-á wée {\ob}\textbf{xálak}{\cb} {\ob}\textbf{biǰóol-a}{\cb} bhíl-a | \gls Ashret-OBL in people[MPL] several-MPL become.PFV"=MPL | \glt `In Ashret people became numerous.'

Knowledge Point: The adjectival agreement is also extended or copied to inflecting adjectives used as adjuncts of other adjectives (primarily bíiḍ- `much'), i.e., as adverbs. That means that the gender and number of the noun that the adjective head agrees with (whether attributively or predicatively) is also lended in agreement to the adjective adjunct, this regardless of the ability of the adjective head itself to inflect (compare with the agreement patterns of adverbs in Gujarati, \citealt{hookjoshi1991}). This is seen in the forms of bíiḍ- in (\ref{ex:10-65})--(\ref{ex:10-69}) and šóo in (\ref{ex:10-70}).
Content 1: \gll {\ob}\textbf{čhéel"=ii} \textbf{phaaidá}{\cb} bi {\ob}\textbf{bíiḍ-u} \textbf{ɡáaḍ-u}{\cb} {\ob}\textbf{kaṛaáu}{\cb} bi {\ob}\textbf{bíiḍ-u} \textbf{ziaát}{\cb} | \gls she.goat-GEN benefit[MSG] also much-MSG big-MSG effort[MSG] also much-MSG great | \glt `There are many benefits of the goat, but they also require a lot of work.'
Content 2: \gll {\ob}\textbf{se}{\cb} heewand-á {\ob}\textbf{bíiḍ-a} \textbf{xušaán}{\cb} hóons"=an de | \gls 3PL.NOM winter-OBL much-MPL happy stay-3PL PST | \glt `They were very happy during the winter.'
Content 3: \gll {\ob}\textbf{kaṭamúš}{\cb} {\ob}\textbf{šóo} \textbf{čaáx}{\cb} bhíl-u hín-u | \gls Katamosh[MSG] good.MSG fat become.PFV"=MSG be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `Katamosh became really fat.'

Knowledge Point: This is also the case with adjuncts in adverbial phrases used predicatively in which the adjunct agrees in gender and number with the noun head of the subject. Again, it is primarily the scalar modifier bíiḍ- `much' that is being used. In (\ref{ex:10-71}), bíiḍ- agrees in feminine gender with iskuúl `school', and in (\ref{ex:10-72}) it agrees in masculine singular with ɡhoóṣṭ `house'.
Content 1: \gll {\ob}\textbf{asíi} \textbf{iskuúl}{\cb} bi asaám the {\ob}\textbf{bíiḍ-i} \textbf{dhúura}{\cb} hín-i | \gls 1PL.GEN school[FSG] also 1PL.ACC to much-F distant be.PRS-F | \glt `Our school is also very far away for us.'
Content 2: \gll {\ob}\textbf{míi} \textbf{ɡhoóṣṭ}{\cb} {\ob}\textbf{bíiḍ-u} \textbf{dhúura}{\cb} hín-u | \gls 1SG.GEN house[MSG] much-MSG distant be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `My house is very far away.'

Knowledge Point: A form of incomplete agreement pattern is seen between an~argument in a~nominalised complement clause and the adjunct of the complement"=taking adjective. In example (\ref{ex:10-73}), the adjunct bíiḍ- agrees with the feminine direct object of the nominalised verb xat `letter', whereas in (\ref{ex:10-74}) and (\ref{ex:10-75}) the choice of the masculine singular seems to be due to its default value rather than one triggered by agreement with any particular argument. This certainly deserves more in"=depth study.\footnote{Note that askóon `easy' is a~non"=inflecting adjective.}
Content 1: \gll {\ob}\textbf{urdú} \textbf{xat}{\cb} čooṇṭainií {\ob}\textbf{bíiḍ-i} \textbf{askóon}{\cb} | \gls Urdu letter[FSG] write.VN much-F easy | \glt `It's very easy to write a~letter in Urdu.'
Content 2: \gll lab utrap"=ainií {\ob}\textbf{bíiḍ-u} \textbf{askóon}{\cb} | \gls fast run-VN much-MSG easy | \glt `It's very easy to run fast.'
Content 3: \gll kuṇaak-á saatainií {\ob}\textbf{bíiḍ-u} \textbf{askóon}{\cb} | \gls children-PL take.care.VN much-MSG easy | \glt `It's very easy to take care of children.'

Knowledge Point: Adjectival agreement of this kind may be extended even to clause"=level adverbial modification, as can be seen in examples (\ref{ex:10-76}) and (\ref{ex:10-77}).
Content 1: \gll aṛó \textbf{bíiḍ-u} bhakulíil-u hín-u | \gls DIST.MSG.NOM much-MSG fatten.PFV"=MSG be.PRS-F | \glt `He has fattened a~lot.'
Content 2: \gll šumaalí húuši \textbf{bíiḍ-i} ziaát teéz bhe nikhéet-i | \gls northern wind[FSG] much-F excessively strong become.CV come.out.PFV"=F | \glt `The North Wind blew as hard as she could.'
